did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Edward Norton Barnhart papers
did.abstract: Edward Norton Barnhart was a professor of Rhetoric at the University of California, Berkeley and also served as bibliographer for the Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Collection there. This collection consists of copies and originals of reports, research papers, and publications related to the Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Collection Study and includes War Relocation Authority (WRA) publications and statistical reports on evacuation and resettlement. The collection also includes correspondence of the Tajiris, mostly regarding the preparation of a pamphlet on the Japanese American war efforts, as well as a small collection of personal records of Peruvian Japanese and their families interned at Santa Fe and Crystal City from the law offices of Wayne M. Collins. Materials in this collection are primarily in English with some in Japanese.
did.langmaterial: Finding aid is written in English.

repository.corpname: University of California, Los Angeles. Library Special Collections.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UC Regents. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Edward Norton Barnhart papers (Collection Number 2010). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Edward Norton Barnhart (1909-1988), Professor Emeritus of Rhetoric at the University of California, Berkeley, served as bibliographer for the university's Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Study (JERS) collection. The JERS project received the Woodrow Wilson Award of the American Political Science Association for the most distinguished work in political science published in 1954. As the bibliographer, he was responsible for creating an inventory for the collection.

Barnhart began his scholarly career in the field of psychology, but after joining the government services as a Public Opinion Analyst in the Office of Facts and Figures (later known as the Office of War Information), he started focusing on issues in communication and public policy. In particular, he was interested in examining the legal implications of government bowing down to public opinion pressures during wartime. Such research was embodied in a book he wrote with two others, titled Prejudice, War and the Constituion (1954), which stems from JERS, and deals with the political characteristics and constitutional significance of the wartime internment of Japanese Americans. He also wrote articles on Peruvian Japanese internees in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of various materials related to the Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Study (JERS) collection at the University of California, Berkeley, such as statistical reports, newsletters, and research papers. A large portion of the collection comprises of War Relocation Authority (WRA) documents and publications from relocation centers. Also included in the collection are approximately 100 letters addressed to and from Larry Tajiri, editor of the Pacific Citizen newspaper, and his wife. Content of these correspondences mainly regard the the preparation of a new pamphlet to be printed by the Japanese American Citizen's League (JACL) on the Japanese American war efforts. In addition, the collection contains photocopied office files of Wayne M. Collins, a civil rights attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) who served as legal counsel for the Peruvian Japanese interned in the United States during World War II, and thus a handful of personal records of Peruvian Japanese and their families interned at Santa Fe and Crystal City. Materials in this collection are primarily in English with some in Japanese.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Preliminary inventory
WRA statistical reports
Copies of reports, publication excerpts, research papers, and bibliographies
WRA reports, newsletters, and summary reports
Camp newsletters
Correspondence of the Tajiris (Mr. and Mrs. Larry Tajiri)
Copies of reports, publications, and a research paper
Office files (photocopies) of Wayne M. Collins

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Japanese American Research Project Collection of Material about Japanese in the United States (Collection 2010) . Available at Library Special Collections, UCLA.

dsc.head: Container List
dsc.p: The Edward Norton Barnhart papers are found in Boxes 46-51 of the Japanese American Research Project Collection of Material about Japanese in the United States (Collection 2010).

did.unittitle: 1. Preliminary inventory

scopecontent.p: The inventory lists the items found within the Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Study (JERS) collection, University of California, Berkeley.

did.unittitle: Inventory list of the Japanese American Evacuation and Resettlement Study (JERS) collection
2. WRA statistical reports

scopecontent.p: Reports relate to the evacuation and resettlement from the War Relocation Authority (WRA) Relocation Planning Division, Statistical Section.

did.unittitle: Reports on weekly leaves and net absences on leave by centers

scopecontent.p: Includes: Weekly Leaves by Centers, weekly report, no. 5-33; Net Absences on Leave by Centers, weekly report, no. 34-133; and Net Absences on Leave, Tule Lake.

did.unittitle: Reports on seasonal leaves from centers

scopecontent.p: Includes: Seasonal Leaves, Departures by Center, State and County of Destination, Weekly Report, no. 31-45; Seasonal Leave by Centers, Weekly Report, County of Destination, no. 1-30; and Seasonal Leaves, Departures by Center, State and County of Destination, Monthly Report, no. 46-47

did.unittitle: Reports on indefinite leaves from centers

scopecontent.p: Includes: General Indefinite Leaves by Centers, Dependents and Workers, semi-monthly report, no. 1-18; Indefinite Leave by Areas, Number of Evacuees on Indefinite Leave Who Have Reported Departures, Arrival or Change of Address by Relocation Areas, States and Important Cities, semi-monthly report, no. 1-38; Indefinite Leaves by Centers, Weekly Report, State of Destination, no. 1-24a; Indefinite Leaves, State of Destination, weekly report, no. 25-30; Indefiniteand Indefinite Leaves by Area, weekly report, no. 16; Indefinite Leaves, Departures by Center, State of Destination, Weekly Report, no. 31-45; Indefinite Leaves, Departures by Center, State of Destination, Monthly Report, no. 46-47; and Indefinite Leave Departures, State of First Destination by Type of Leave, monthly report, no. 2-4

did.unittitle: Reported Relocation by States, monthly report, no. 1-12
Returns to West Coast, City, Cumulative, monthly report, no. 1-12; and Returns to West Coast, County and Citizenship, Cumulative, monthly report, no. 1-12

Terminal Departures from Centers, State of First Destination by Center, weekly report, no. 1-48; and Terminal Departures from Centers, Cumulative Summary, State of First Destination by Centers, monthly report, no. 1-12
Selective Service and Volunteers, Weekly Report, no. 10-52
Reported Casualties Among Soldiers of Japanese Descent, by State, County, and City of Pre-Evacuation Address. With Supplements, no. 1-10

scopecontent.p: For the States of California, Oregon, Washington and Arizona, and Territories of Alaska and Hawaii

did.unittitle: Cumulative Casualties by Center (Reported Casualties Among Soldiers of Japanese Ancestry by Location of Next of Kin and Source of Information), no. 1-15
3. Copies of reports, publication excerpts, research papers, and bibliographies

scopecontent.p: Materials relate to Japanese workers in the U.S., anti-Japanese attitudes, and the impact of the war on Japanese American communities.

did.unittitle: United States Bureau of the Census reports, Japanese Employed Workers 14 Years Old and Over by Sex, Nativity, Major Occupation, and Industry Group, for Counties and Urban Places

scopecontent.p: In the states of California, Oregon and Washington

did.unittitle: Editorials from The Pacific Rural Press
Excerpts from the California Fruit Growers; and Excerpts from the Western Grower and Shipper
Helen E. Hennefrund, Bibliography on Japanese in American Agriculture
Reports from the US Department of Agriculture on the Japanese in American agriculture

scopecontent.p: Lloyd H. Fisher and Ralph L. Nielsen, The Japanese in California Agriculture. Testimony submitted to the Select Committee Investigating National Defense Migration. March 1942; Adon Poli, Japanese Farm Holders on the Pacific Coast. December 1944; Walter C. McKain, Jr., When the Japanese Return to California. December 1944; Walter C. McKain, Jr., Imperial Valley holds an 'Anti-Japs' meeting. February 1945.

did.unittitle: Los Angeles County Farm Bureau Monthly, vol. XV, no. 11-12 (2 copies), and vol. XVI, no. 1
Excerpts of various publications re the Japanese in American agriculture

scopecontent.p: Sources include House Committee on Immigration, Berkeley Gazette, Associated Farmer, and Pacific Rural Press.

did.unittitle: Tamotsu Shibutani, The Initial Impact of the War on the Japanese Communities in the San Francisco Bay Region: A Preliminary Report, Berkeley
Richard Nishimoto, Chapter V: "Japanese in Domestic Service"
Richard Nishimoto, Chapter VI: "Japanese in Personal Service and Urban Trade"

George Yasukochi, A Study of the Vocational Experiences of University of California Alumni of Japanese Ancestry, Berkeley; and Dorothy Sheets, Anti-Japanese Agitation in California Studied at Three Periods of Crisis, Whittier College (M.A. thesis)
Chitoshi Yanaga, "Comments and Suggestions," "The Nature of Anti-Oriental Attitude," and Bibliography
4.WRA reports, newsletters, and summary reports

scopecontent.p: Materials are those through which the War Relocation Authority (WRA) provided information about the Relocation Program.

WRA, information bulletins to the evacuees, written in Japanese and in English
WRA, Second Quarterly Report and Semi-Annual Report
WRA, Colorado River Relocation Center, Family Welfare Section, The Story of the Family Welfare Section
WRA, Community Analysis Section, reports

轉住計画の全貌「轉住所住民の心得」 Tenjū keikaku no zenbou: 'tenjūsho jūmin no kokoroe' [Full details about the relocation program], Washington D.C.
WRA, All Center Conference, Salt Lake City, Utah
5. Camp newsletters

scopecontent.p: These publications from various assembly centers and relocation camps report on conditions of their institutions.

did.unittitle: Information Concerning Tule Lake Center; and 「ツーリレツキ出発期日確定す、ラファブリッジ氏より今朝発表さる」 [Tule Lake internees to be notified of day of transfer to Tule Lake]

scopecontent.p: Published by the Central Utah Relocation Project, Topaz, Utah. In English and Japanese

did.unittitle: Civil Liberties and Test Cases

scopecontent.p: Legal Committee Report, Community Council, Topaz, Utah

scopecontent.p: Fighting Americans, Too! published by the historical committee of the Volunteers for Victory, Topaz, Utah; Volunteers for Victory published by the Resident Council for Japanese American Civil Rights, Topaz, Utah; Reinstitution of Selective Service published by the Citizens Committee and Community Council, Central Utah Project, Topaz, Utah; and All Aboard a special publication of the Citizens Committee and Community Council, Central Utah Project, Topaz, Utah

did.unittitle: scattered issues of the Tanforan Tantalizer, vol. I, no. 1, 7, 10, 12, 14, & 19
did.unitdate: 1942 May 15, June 27, July 15 & 25, August 8, and September 8

scopecontent.p: Newsletter for the Tanforan Assembly Center at San Bruno, California

did.unittitle: Denson Magnet, vol. I, no. 1

scopecontent.p: Magazine published by the Document Section, Jerome Relocation Center, Denson, Arkansas

did.unittitle: Issei, Nisei, Kibei: The U.S. has put 110, 000 people of Japanese blood in "protective custody"

scopecontent.p: The English version which originally appeared in the April 1944 issue of Fortune Magazine was reprinted as the Gila News-Courier Supplement (n.d.), and its Japanese translation in ten installments from April 20 to May 16, 1944 in the Gila News-Courier Japanese secton. The Gila News-Courier was the newspaper for the Gila River Relocation Center in Arizona.

did.unittitle: The Pen

scopecontent.p: A special anniversary issue published by the Outpost, Rohwer Relocation Center, Relocation, Arkansas

did.unittitle: Family Welfare Orientation Program

scopecontent.p: Report prepared by the Colorado River Relocation Center, Poston, Arizona

did.unittitle: America in the War and America in the Peace

scopecontent.p: A copy of an address delivered by Ralph P. Merritt, Manzanar Relocation Center Director

did.unittitle: Correspondence and documents re Charlotte B. DeForest, WRA Counselor, and adult education programs in the Manzanar Relocation Center, Manzanar, California

scopecontent.p: A couple of items written in Japanese

did.unittitle: 6. Correspondence of the Tajiris

scopecontent.p: Larry Tajiri was the editor of the Pacific Citizen newspaper. These correspendences mostly re the preparation of a new pamphlet by the Japanense American Citizens League (JACL) on the Japanese American war efforts.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of the Tajiris (Mr. and Mrs. Larry Tajiri)
7. Copies of reports, publications, and a research paper

scopecontent.p: Materials concern the postwar resettlement of evacuees and the effect of evacuation on the Japanese community in Seattle

did.unittitle: Reports, bulletins and leaflets on the postwar resettlement of evacuees
Documents re the Chicago Resettlers Committee

scopecontent.p: Includes scattered issues of the Chicago Resettler, March 29, 1946-June 1947 (6 issues total), and mimeographed reports of the Committee, 1946-1947

did.unittitle: S. Frank Miyamoto and Robert W. O'Brien, A Survey of Some Changes in the Seattle Japanese Community Resulting from the Evacuation

scopecontent.p: Unpublished paper

did.unittitle: 8. Office files of Wayne M. Collins

scopecontent.p: Wayne M. Collins (1900-1974) was a civil rights attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) who served as legal counsel for the Peruvian Japanese interned in the United States during World War II.

Records and documents relating to a test suit filed by Iwamori Sakasegawa before the US District Court

scopecontent.p: Iwamori Sakasegawa, along with Chika Yamasaki, was one of two Peruvian Japanese to file test suits on June 25, 1946 to prevent deportation to Japan, charging that they were kidnapped by the US Military Police.

did.unittitle: Records and documents relating to a test suit filed by Chika Yamasaki before the US District Court

scopecontent.p: Chika Yamasaki, along with Iwamori Sakasegawa, was one of two Peruvian Japanese to file test suits on June 25, 1946 to prevent deportation to Japan, charging that they were kidnapped by the US Military Police.
